monogr.title: A triumph of truth. Or Declaration of the doctrine concerning euangelicall counsayles; lately deliuered in Oxford by Humfrey Leech M. of Arts, & minister. With relation of sondry occurrents, and particularly of D. King, the Vicechancellour, his exorbitant proceedings agains the sayd H.L. vpon his constant propugnation thereof. Also the peculiar motiues, ensuing therevpon, which perswaded him to renounce the faction of hereticall congregations, & and to embrace the vnity of the Catholique Church
monogr.author: Leech, Humphrey

div.head: An Aduertisement to the Reader.
div.p: I Desire thee (good Reader) to vnderstand, that I freely offered vnto my aforesayd Iudges, and vnto other learned men in Oxford, and elswhere, to take their choyce of any of theis four reasonable propositions.
FIRST. If I can not approoue, and iustify my Doctrine, by the vniforme consent of all Antiquity, successiuely from the Apostles, I vvill publickly abiure it.
SECOND. If my Iudges can disprooue it by the verdict of any one Oxthodox vvriter, that euer liued in the communion of holy Church, I vvill recant it.
THIRD. Jf I can not prooue that their opinion is heresy, and condemned by the Church, J vvill intertayn it.

FOVRTH. If any article of Religion, accepted by the Church of ENGLAND it self,
and established by vniforme consent, be plainely against my Doctrine, I vvill submitt my self vnto it, and yeald vnto this manner of triall.

p.hi: Theis petitions, & demands (though full of equity) could find no acceptance at my Iudges hands. Consider therefore the quality of theis men, & the goodnes of their Religion: which hauing no conformable grounds, sustayneth it self meerely by fraud, insolency, and oppression.
